summary: Block Access to North Korea Act of 2016 or BANK Act of 2016 This bill requires the President to impose sanctions pursuant to the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, with specified waiver authority, against a person that continues to knowingly and directly provide specialized financial messaging services to, or to knowingly enable or facilitate access to such messaging services for:   the Central Bank of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (North Korea),  a financial institution that facilitates any transaction or provides significant financial services for nuclear development or proliferation on North Korea's behalf, or  a person identified on the list of specially designated nationals and blocked persons maintained by the Department of the Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control for assisting North Korea's nuclear development or proliferation efforts.
predicted_summary: Block Grant to North Korea Act of 2016 - Directs the Secretary of Commerce to enter into agreements with North Korea to block access to the North Korean financial system and to provide financial services and technical assistance to the government of North Korea.North Korea Continues to threaten the United States and its allies in the region with provocations, including North Korean provocations.Authorizes the President to impose sanctions against: (1) individuals who knowingly and directly provide specialized financial messaging services to, or facilitate direct or indirect access to, North Korea; and (2) any financial institution that facilitates any transaction or transactions or provides significant financial services for nuclear development or proliferation for North Korea.Directs the President to waive such sanctions if: (1) the person is subject to a sanctions regime that requires it to eliminate the knowing provision of such messaging services and to: (2) the recipient of such services is not prohibited from using such services; and (3) such recipient has, pursuant to that sanctions regime, terminated such services due to their knowing nature and the ability to access such services without authorization from the President.Directs financial institutions to serve as intermediaries with access to such messaging services. Directs a financial institution to provide financial services to: (1) consumers with access through instant messaging services; and (2) to provide such services to a consumer or a business owner.

summary: Social Security Protection Act of 2011 - Makes it out of order in the Senate or the House of Representatives to consider any legislation that: (1) increases the retirement age or the early retirement age for individuals receiving benefits under title II (Old Age, Survivors, and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act on or after the enactment of this Act; (2) reduces cost-of-living increases for them; (3) reduces benefit payment amounts for them; or (4) creates private retirement accounts for any of the OSADI benefits they receive.
predicted_summary: Social Security Act of 2011 - Amends the Public Health Service Act to: (1) repeal and replace the Social Security Administration (SSA) program with the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) contract; and (2) establish a national retirement savings account for eligible retirement-age eligible beneficiaries.Social Security is not in a crisis or going bankrupt, as the Social Security trust funds have been running surpluses for the last quarter of a century.Social Security benefits for retirees and their dependents are among the highest in the nation.Social Security Administration (SSA) and the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) report that: (1) the retirement age for current and future Social Security beneficiaries is 65 years of age, and (2) Social Security benefits have already been cut by 13 percent, with the exception of Medicare and Medicaid.Amends the Social Security Act to:  (1) reduce benefit payment amounts for individuals receiving benefits under title ii of the Act on or after the date of enactment of this Act; and (2) reduce cost-of-living increases for individuals who receive benefits under Title ii. (Medicare) and the social security act (Social Security Act-Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide for individuals under the age of 25 who have no children and no dependents; (3) increase benefit payment requirements for individuals with disabilities, as determined under this Act, and (4) create private retirement accounts for any of the benefits individuals receive under title II. (Sec. ii.Sets forth provisions regarding: (1) the right of the Speaker to suspend the application of this Act only by a rule or order proposing only to waive such provisions by an affirmative vote of two-thirds of the members present and voting; and (2) the use of such Act in the House of Representatives as a substitute for the Speaker of the House.

summary: Gold King Mine Spill Accountability Act of 2016 This bill requires the Department of Justice (DOJ) to appoint a special investigator to investigate: (1) who was at fault for the discharge of contaminated water from the Gold King Mine north of Silverton, Colorado, into Cement Creek; (2) which individuals were responsible for the decisions that led to the spill; and (3) what downstream environmental effects were caused by the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) actions, or inactions, after the spill.  The bill: (1) entitles individuals to receive compensation for a claim filed, or civil action brought, under the Federal Tort Claims Act relating to an injury resulting from the spill, and (2) establishes within the EPA the Office of Gold King Mine Spill Claims for processing claims of allowable damages resulting from the spill. The EPA may provide compensation for a claim in an amount greater than $25,000 without the prior approval of DOJ. The EPA must fund the implementation of the long-term monitoring program developed by the Long-Term Impact Review Team of New Mexico, for the water quality of the Animas and San Juan Rivers. The EPA may not finalize or work on any rules (including those not related to the spill) until all claims have been paid, except rules that are necessary to address an imminent threat to public health or safety, or other emergency.
predicted_summary: Requires the Attorney General to appoint a special investigator, dedicated full time, to conduct an investigation to determine: (1) who was at fault for the gold king mine spill; and (2) which individuals were responsible for the decisions that led to the spill.Directs the Special Investigator to appoint and fix the pay of additional personnel who are full-time officers or employees of the united States. Requires the special investigator to: (1) appoint, fix, and pay additional personnel; and (2) report to the head of any Federal agency or department of state or local government with respect to any matter that the Special investigator is investigating.Requires a person to appear before a united States district court for an order requiring that person to give testimony, produce evidence, or both, relating to the matter under investigation. Requires: (1) the attendance of witnesses and the production of evidence at any designated place of hearing within the united States; and (2) the court to which such an order is made within the United States.Sets forth procedures for the selection of a special investigator and for the conduct of the investigation.Directs the President pro tempore of the Senate to report to Congress on the status of the Pacific Northwest gold mine spill and to advise the Secretary of Energy on the adequacy, safety, and effectiveness of the National Environmental Policy Act. Authorizes the appointment of a special investigator to investigate the impact of the spill on the environment, water quality, or the environment of a state or local government affected area downstream. Directs each member of the House of Representatives representing a state that includes the Pacific NW watersheds and any affected area upstream of the gold king mine.Requires the Administrator to provide compensation in the amount greater than $25,000 without prior written approval of the Attorney General (or a designee), as appropriate.Prohibits the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) from paying for the cost of: (1) property loss, (2) water supplies, or (3) any other loss that is incurred by an injured person to pay for water supplies or equipment to treat water during the period for which a water supply of the injured person was compromised by the spill; (4) any cost resulting from lost tribal subsistence from hunting, fishing, firewood gathering, timbering, grazing, or agricultural activities, or from lost use for traditional or ceremonial uses, conducted on land or using water damaged by the gold king mine spill; and (5) any costs resulting from such loss that are not appropriate for inclusion in any other federal program.Amends Federal law to: (1) make a business loss eligible for inclusion in this Act; and (2) allow a claim for damages resulting from the gold king mine spill to be paid from unobligated funds appropriated to the Environmental Protection Agency for a fiscal year. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to require the Administrator of a business to report to Congress on the extent to which such a loss exceeds the maximum allowable limit.Requires Federal employees, contractors, or subcontractors to report to Congress on the extent to which they have violated Federal law.Requires the Administrator to fund the implementation of the Long-Term Monitoring Program, which shall: (1) provide full disclosure to the public of applicable water quality and sediment data; and (2) enable a clear and meaningful comparison between those standards and all relevant water quality standards. Authorizes the Administrator, in order to be funded, to administer the program.Fatalities in the Gold King Mine and Coconino National Forest Water Pollution Control Act of 2001 - Directs the Secretary of the Interior to investigate and report to Congress regarding the discharge of mercury from the mine north of silverton, Colorado, into cement creek that occurred while contractors of the Environmental Protection Agency were conducting an investigation of the gold king mine.

summary:
Rural Broadband Access Enhancement Act - Amends the Rural Electrification Act of 1936 to redefine "eligible rural community."

Permits a loan or loan guarantee applicant in an area where 40% of the residents are without broadband access to qualify with a 10% loan equity position.

Provides for: (1) paperwork reduction; and (2) program outreach to underserved areas.

Prohibits loan or loan guarantees for new broadband service in communities with three or more service providers.

Provides that for each fiscal year: (1) not more than 10% of program funds shall be available to providers with more than 10% of national subscriber lines; and (2) 40% of program funds shall be available to providers with between 2%-10% of national subscriber lines.

Revises the amortization period from the life of the asset to 35 years.

Requires an annual broadband program report to Congress.
predicted_summary: Rural Broadband Access Enhancement Act of 2004 - Amends the Rural Fiber Infrastructure Act of 1936 to: (1) make eligible rural communities in the United States eligible for rural broadband access; and (2) require the Secretary of the Interior to establish a regional rural broadband plan. (3) This Act amends the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) rules governing the application process for rural rural communities. (4) Amends provisions of the National Rural Landscape and Urban Development Act to establish an eligible rural community (IRC) in states where the median household income is less than $1,000 for a family of four living in an urbanized area contiguous and adjacent to such a rural community. (5)Directs the Secretary to not approve an application to serve: (1) an area in which at least 40 percent of the population does not have access to broadband service; or (2) any other area where at least 50 percent of residents do not have broadband service. (3) The Secretary shall take steps necessary to reduce the paperwork required of applicants under this Act.Directs the Secretary to conduct outreach designed to inform the population of areas in which there is no or limited broadband service. (Sec. 3) Amends the Rural Electrification Act of 1936 to prohibit the loan or loan guarantee program for new broadband service in communities with at least three or more service providers.Amends the Rural Electrification Act of 1936 to: (1) extend through FY2018 the Federal loan guarantees program for entities with less than 2 percent of the installed telephone subscriber lines in the aggregate in the United States; and (2) provide loans or loan guarantees to entities with more than 10 percent of installed telephone suscriber lines.Directs the Secretary to annually report to Congress on the status of the program, and to the House and the Senate on the progress of the grant program.

summary:
Wounded Warrior Transition Assistance Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of each military department to provide each reserve member of that department who is being evaluated for separation or retirement for disability, or for placement on the temporary disability retired list or inactive status list, the option to remain on active duty during such evaluation in order to continue to receive military pay and allowances, until the member is: (1) cleared to return to duty; or (2) separated, retired, or placed on the temporary disability retired or inactive status list.

Requires each Secretary to retain on active duty (for pay and allowances purposes) a reserve member who incurs an injury or illness while on active duty, is being discharged or separated from the Armed Forces, or is being released from active duty, and is not being evaluated in connection with such discharge, separation, or release, until the member is: (1) retired or placed on the temporary disability retired or inactive status list; or (2) determined ineligible for such care or benefits based solely upon the injury or illness.

Requires military human resources commands to return to active duty during their evaluation period reserve members who request such option.

Encourages the use of local residences by reserve members during such transition periods.

Authorizes the use of Defense Health Program funds for reserve members who become ill or injured while on active duty and separate as a result of such illness or injury.

Provides for the assignment of Judge Advocate General personnel to assist members of the Armed Forces (members) in connection with the medical discharge process and disability evaluations.

Expresses support for access of veterans service organizations to military facilities to provide counseling and services to members.
predicted_summary: Requires the Secretary of the Defense to: (1) give a member of a reserve component the option to remain on active duty in order to continue to receive pay and allowances; and (2) allow a member to return to the active-duty after the date of the enactment of this Act.Requires the Secretary to: (1) elect at any time to retain on active duty a member of a reserve component under the Department of Defense who incurs an injury or illness while serving a military warrant, is being discharged or separated from the Armed Forces, or is not being evaluated by a physical evaluation board; and (2) elects to be discharged, separated, or released, as applicable, from active duty.Authorizes the Secretary of the Army to: (1) return a member of a reserve component to active duty; and (2) make an election for such position. (3) Members of the National Labor Relations Committee (ULRB) who have been discharged from active duty may elect to participate in the election.Authorizes appropriations through FY2018 for the development of a flexible human resources command in the Army, the Marine Corps, the Army's Human Resources Command, and the Coast Guard to discharge human resources functions with respect to members of the armed forces.Authorizes the Secretary of Defense to pay reasonable expenses of transportation, lodging, and meals incurred by a member residing at a member's permanent place of residence during the period the member is on active duty.Defense Health Program Support Programs for Reserve Components. (Sec. 6) Support programs for such members of the Reserve Components include the following programs: (1) non-clinical case management; (2) tricare program advisors; and (3) psychological health programs.Requires the Secretary to ensure that: (1) each member of the armed forces under the jurisdiction of such Secretary who is undergoing medical discharge from the military receives appropriate assistance on all legal matters relating to medical discharge; and (2) each military department, after the date of the discharge, to provide such assistance to each member at the commencement of the medical discharge process.Directs the Secretary of Defense to ensure that, at the commencement of a disability evaluation, a member of the armed forces, the judge advocate general's corps under the jurisdiction of such a judge has the capacity to provide legal assistance on all legal matters relating to such evaluation.Requires: (1) members of the judge advocate generals' corps to practice before the Department of Veterans Affairs in connection with representation of members of their respective military units undergoing disability evaluation. (2) Members of the Judge Advocate General's Corps of the member of the armed forces practicing before the department of veterans affairs if requested by the Member of the Armed Forces.Directs the Secretary of Defense to distribute information regarding the status of the wounded warrior resource center to members of the armed forces and their dependents at such facilities or locations.Directs the Secretary of Defense to recover, and make available available to the affected individual, any amount derived from, erroneous payments to contractors.
